review.title: Measuring Inconsistency in Probabilistic Knowledge Bases
review.abstract: This paper develops an inconsistency measure on conditional probabilistic knowledge bases. The measure is based on fundamental principles for inconsistency measures and thus provides a solid theoretical framework for the treatment of inconsistencies in probabilistic expert systems. We illustrate its usefulness and immediate application on several examples and present some formal results. Building on this measure we use the Shapley value-a well-known solution for coalition games-to define a sophisticated indicator that is not only able to measure inconsistencies but to reveal the causes of inconsistencies in the knowledge base. Altogether these tools guide the knowledge engineer in his aim to restore consistency and therefore enable him to build a consistent and usable knowledge base that can be employed in probabilistic expert systems.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Fifth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2009)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Fifth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2009)

metadata.title: Measuring Inconsistency in Probabilistic Knowledge Bases

sections.text: This paper develops an inconsistency measurement based on conditional probabilistic knowledge. This metric is based on basic principles of inconsistency measurement, providing a solid theoretical framework for dealing with inconsistencies in probabilistic expert systems. We illustrate their usefulness and immediate application using several examples and present some formal results. Building on this metric, we use the Shapley Value - a well-known solution for coalition games - to define a sophisticated indicator that is not only able to measure inconsistencies, but also to detect the causes of inconsistencies in the knowledge base. Overall, these tools guide the Knowledge Engineer in his goal of restoring consistency, enabling him to build a consistent and usable knowledge base that can be used in probabilistic expert systems.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Even if these inconsistencies often affect only a small part of the knowledge base or are composed of only a few differences in the way they occur in practice, it is an important field in which there are many proposals to deal with the inconsistency in classical logic.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: We work with a propositional framework of random variables. Let V = {V1,.., Vn} be a set of propositional variables with finite domains Dom (V1),.., Dom (Vn). The set V is assumed to be given for all coming definitions. An expression of the form Vi = vi is literally called when vi is in the domain of Vi, i. e. vi, Dom (Vi). The language LV is generated with the connectors ¬, and on the letters in V in the usual way. We shorten the conjunctions A-B by AB and negation ¬ A by the binary variable, i. e, it is Dom (V) = {true, false}, we shorten V = true by only V and V = false by V. We write > for obtautological formulas, e.

sections.heading: 3 Determining Consistency
sections.text: It does not always have to be the case that there is a probability distribution PR with PR | = R for a knowledge base R (e.g. for the knowledge base R = {(A | B) [0.5], (B | >) [0.5], (A | >) [0.1] with words A, B, there is no distribution PR with PR | = R. Therefore, for a specific knowledge base R we are interested in determining whether R is consistent (if there is at least a distribution PR with PR | = R) or inconsistent (if there is no such PR).In the following, we reduce this problem to a satisfaction problem similar to the approaches in (Hansen and Jaumard, 1996; Andersen and Pretolani, 2001), which consider purely propositional knowledge bases without conditional limitations.

sections.heading: 4 Measuring Inconsistency
sections.text: The simple information that a knowledge base R is inconsistent is not always sufficient for knowledge engineering and analysis. To repair the knowledge base, more detailed information about inconsistency is needed. There is much work on analyzing inconsistency in qualitative frameworks, see e.g. (Knight, 2001; Wong and Besnard, 2001; Hunter and Konieczny, 2006), but there is very little work on analyzing inconsistency in quantitative frameworks, especially in probabilistic frameworks such as the one discussed here (Finthammer et al., 2007). While (Finthammer et al., 2007) it is mainly about solving inconsistencies by heuristics, here we take a more formal approach to inconsistency analysis by formalizing and developing an inconsistency measurement on probable knowledge bases.

sections.heading: 5 Determining the Causes of Inconsistency
sections.text: In Example 2, it was shown that the first constraint (A | B) [1] had to be modified to restore the consistency of the knowledge base R2, which might lead one to believe that this constraint alone is responsible for the inconsistency in R2. However, if one looks more closely at R2, one can see that the situation is symmetrical in all three constraints; the optimization problem has more than one solution, such as η 2 = 1 also solves the inconsistency (equal to zero for all other values) with the same inconsistency measure. In fact, most inconsistent knowledge databases exhibit this behavior because it is best for the optimization problem to change as few values of the probability constraints as possible. Normally, one is not only interested in determining a simple value of consistency, but in determining the causes of the inconsistency and ultimately restoring consistency. In Example 2, all three general constraints are equally responsible for the rule 2 (where we are responsible for consistency).

sections.heading: 5.1 Coalition Game Theory
sections.text: The game theory of the Coalition refers to games where players can form coalitions to maximize their own payout of the game (= coalition). Let P denote the amount of power. Definition 3 (Coalition game): A Coalition game (N, v) consists of a number of players N N and a function v: P (N) → R with v (4) = 0 and v (S T) ≥ v (S) + v (T) for S, T N with S T =.For any coalition C N of players in the game, the value v (C) determines the payout of that coalition. Since this payout must be distributed among the members of C, each player must evaluate for himself which coalition must be formed to maximize his own expected payout. Not every player must expect the same payout for himself, as the players may be more or less important for the formation of coalitions. sections.heading: 6 Summary and Discussion
sections.text: We developed an inconsistency measurement based on conditional probabilistic knowledge and demonstrated that this measurement fulfills several desirable characteristics. We used this measurement and the known Shapley value to define a more differentiated measurement that gives the Knowledge Engineer the means to restore the consistency of a knowledge base by identifying the causes of the inconsistency. Due to its inheritance from the Shapley value, the Shapley inconsistency measurement fulfills several beautiful characteristics. The examples in this work were calculated by a prototype implementation of the Inc. * and SRInc. function in Java that uses the free optimization software OpenOpt2 to address the optimization problems of the OPTR.The inconsistency measurement and inconsistency measurements described here are generally useful when it comes to data from heterogeneous sources, such as information fusion or faith revision (Bloch, Hunter, 2001, Albero, R� n).

Here, we aim at analyzing inconsistencies in a probabilistic framework and in particular measuring inconsistency in conditional probabilistic knowledge bases (Nute and Cross, 2002; Kern-Isberner, 2001; Benferhat et al., 1999; Rödder and Meyer, 1996).

Here, we aim at analyzing inconsistencies in a probabilistic framework and in particular measuring inconsistency in conditional probabilistic knowledge bases (Nute and Cross, 2002; Kern-Isberner, 2001; Benferhat et al., 1999; Rödder and Meyer, 1996).

In contrast to probabilistic networks like Bayesian Networks (Pearl, 1998) conditional probabilistic knowledge bases do not demand the complete specification of every conditional probability of every probabilistic dependence and thus do not define a unique probability distribution as the underlying model.
Nonetheless, using maximum entropy methods (Grove et al., 1994) one can determine a single probability distribution that describes the specified knowledge in an unbiased way.
There is very little work on the treatment of inconsistencies in a conditional probabilistic framework (Rödder and Xu, 2001; Finthammer et al., 2007).
The method described in (Finthammer et al., 2007) consists of a set of heuristics that are used to restore consistency in a knowledge base.

While (Finthammer et al., 2007) is mainly concerned with resolving inconsistencies using heuristics, here we take a more formal approach in the analysis of inconsistency by formalizing and developing an inconsistency measure on probabilistic knowledge bases.

metadata.abstractText: This paper develops an inconsistency measure on conditional probabilistic knowledge bases. The measure is based on fundamental principles for inconsistency measures and thus provides a solid theoretical framework for the treatment of inconsistencies in probabilistic expert systems. We illustrate its usefulness and immediate application on several examples and present some formal results. Building on this measure we use the Shapley value—a well-known solution for coalition games—to define a sophisticated indicator that is not only able to measure inconsistencies but to reveal the causes of inconsistencies in the knowledge base. Altogether these tools guide the knowledge engineer in his aim to restore consistency and therefore enable him to build a consistent and usable knowledge base that can be employed in probabilistic expert systems.
